journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Structural dynamics of the foldable stairs

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Precision Instruments and Mechanology, Tsinghua University, PR China
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Centre for Advanced Mechanisms and Robotics, Tianjin University, PR China
3School of Physical Sciences and Engineering, King’s College London, University of London, UK

author-notes.corresp: Jing-Shan Zhao, Department of Precision Instruments and Mechanology, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, PR China. Email: jingshanzhao@mail.tsinghua.edu.cn

abstract.p: This article proposes a structural dynamics method for foldable stairs based on transfer matrix. The stairs are made up of a number of identical scissor-like elements which are supposed to be Euler–Bernoulli beams. The dynamics of each segment beam between every two adjacent revolute joints can be precisely expressed by the transfer matrix of the segment with the variables of boundary conditions of the joints. Therefore, the structural dynamics of the whole stairs is built using the least number of variables compared with the traditional methods. In addition, this method avoids the problem of the traditional transfer-matrix method that the number of variables greatly increases when there are a huge number of cross-joints within a structure.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The deployable concept was initially coined by Fuller in the early 1960s1 and was used in the movable theatre in 1960s by a Spain architect, Pinero.2,3 From the viewpoint of the mechanism theory, the deployable structures were investigated as early as the 19th century by Sarrus and Bricard, and in the early 20th century by Bennett et al.4 In fact, many deployable systems can often be found in some biological organisms in nature. The statics,5,6 kinematics,7,8 dynamics,9–11 and the force accommodation control operations12 of the deployable structures are widely investigated in the last two decades.

To monitor the structural health, vibration-based methods are the most conventional approaches. Numerical evaluation of vibration-based methods was investigated for the damage assessment of cable-stayed bridges.13 The performance of the method for real-life situations is highly dependent on the accuracy of the important modal features of the structure extracted from output-only vibration measurements.14 Therefore, the structural dynamics of the foldable stairs should be analyzed to reveal its vibration characteristics before real applications. Multi-input, single-output semi-active fuzzy controller for vibration control of seismically excited small-scale buildings is developed through integration of a set of model-based fuzzy controllers that are formulated in terms of linear matrix inequalities such that the global asymptotical stability is guaranteed and the performance on transient responses is also satisfied.15

Homogenized beam model was proposed to reproduce the dynamical behavior of unconstrained layer damping beams with a thick viscoelastic layer.16 A meta-heuristic algorithm17 was proposed to solve the multi-objective combinatorial optimization problems. Four beam-collapse modes were discussed for the progressive collapse analysis associated with debris loading when disengaged structural components fall into lower parts of the structure.18 A family of explicit methods were investigated19 to obtain unconditional stability and second-order accuracy. An integral-type quadratic functional20 was proposed as the performance index to derive the optimal control policy for the earthquake-excited structures. Hybrid computational strategy of combining generic algorithm with a compatible local search operator21 was proposed and the hybrid time-domain method was investigated22 to obtain a higher accurate solution of structural dynamics problems. To effectively solve the structural dynamics, this article proposes a theoretically accurate method based on transfer matrix. It takes the advantage of the fact that the stairs are made up of a number of identical units of scissor-like element (SLE) to establish the structural dynamics via assembling the unit dynamics model based on Euler–Bernoulli beam assumption. And therefore, this method is accurate both in geometry and in physical aspect.

A most common characteristic of the deployable structure is that it always consists of identical units, which are composed of pairs of bars connected at joint that allows compact and deployed configurations.23 Chen and You24 discussed the creations of 6R linkages by combining Goldberg 5R linkages. Liu and Chen25 presented a method to build deployable assemblies using the Myard linkages. Kang and Miranda26 proposed a numerical method to simulate the kinematic and dynamic activities of a crane. In some cases, the structural responses are in dependency of uncertain load processes and environmental influences.27 Passive tuned mass damper for reducing the dynamic responses of structures under near-fault earthquake excitations was proposed to simulate the near-fault ground motion.28 Polynomial chaos representation for identification of mechanical characteristics of instrumented structures was investigated to monitor the structures by providing more realistic models for mechanical behavior or input values for their parameters.29 Among deployable structures, the foldable structures based on SLEs3,23 with large span are generally used in engineering. An SLE is one planar II-Assur group30 in mechanism theory. From a geometric viewpoint, the SLE is a pair of planar links that are connected at their intermediate points by a revolute joint which allows them to freely rotate about an axis perpendicular to their common plane but restrains all other degrees of freedom (DOFs), while their end points are hinged to the end points of other SLEs.31 When one or more such elements are added to the mechanism, the number of actuators needed to control the mechanism will not change.30

Optimal designs of the foldable structures based on structural steel analysis 32 and colony optimization algorithm33 were investigated and utilized in the foldable structures. Optimum design34 in structures provides new and high-performance computing methods35 for foldable structures. Hachem et al.36 surveyed biological systems in terms of their morphology, kinematics and structural characteristics, and discussed the similarities between biological systems and the existing deployable structures.

Applications of deployable structures in space engineering and nonconventional structures have extensively propelled the research on the mechanics and design of large flexible structures.37 The deployable structures were widely researched in space engineering with the increasing needs of complex space missions in the 1970s.38,39 Recently, deployable structures are often used in the situations requiring minimal damage to structural components during repeated deployment and fold.40 In civil engineering, foldable stairs seldom appears, while the steel-reinforced concrete stairs are most popular in the current apartments. A structural concrete analysis using rigid-body-spring networks41 and the numerical analysis of debonding mechanisms in reinforced concrete beams with fiber polymer42 are widely probed for the applications in the concrete structures. With the emergence of high-stiffness, high-strength, and low-weight alloy material in the recent years, the foldable stairs are becoming feasible in engineering. However, the structural dynamics of foldable stairs should be different from those of fixed structural or steel enforced stairs. Consequently, this article focuses on the structural dynamics of the foldable stairs and discusses the possible applications in engineering.

sec.title: Mechanism of the foldable stairs
sec.p:
The primary unit of the stairs adopts the planar parallelogram four-bar mechanism, C0A1C1B0, shown in Figure 1. So, the beam, A1C1B1, not only has the moving flexibility of a mechanism but also has the high stiffness and high strength of statically indeterminate structures when considering that every side of the stair has one such parallelogram four-bar mechanism connected by five axes which are represented by A1, C1, B1, B0, and C0 in Figure 1. Another four-bar linkage, A0DA1C0, is a driving crank-rocker mechanism which controls the deploying or folding of the whole stairs. Figure 1.
The driving mechanism and the first stair of the foldable stairs.

The beams A1C1B1 and B0C1A2 jointed at C1 form one SLE, A1B1B0A2. From the geometry point of view, SLE A1B1B0A2 shown in Figure 1 is a pair of planar links that are connected by one pin at their common middle point, C1, through a revolute joint which allows them to freely rotate around an axis perpendicular to their common plane, but restrains all other DOFs while their end points allow to be hinged to the end points of other SLEs. When one or more such elements are added to the mechanism shown in Figure 1, the number of actuators needed to control the mechanism will not change. Figure 2 illustrates the deployable stairs that consists of seven complete SLEs. The stairs can be deployed for use and folded to save the occupied space after utilization. The stairs form a statically indeterminate structure after deploying because the ground and the roof as well will provide real supports. So, both the statics and the dynamics of the foldable stairs are different from those of the traditional ones. The structural dynamics of the foldable stairs cannot be directly analyzed with the general methods, either. Figure 2.
The deployed and folded stairs.
Therefore, what follows will focus on the structural dynamics of the foldable stairs and investigate the possible applications in engineering.

sec.title: Structural dynamics of the stairs
sec.p: When the crank of the driving four-bar mechanism, A0DA1C0, rotates to the dead point,30 crank A0D and link DA1 will keep in one line, and the rocker C0A1 is perpendicular to the upper ceiling. Simultaneously, a lock mechanism will make sure of such a pose during applications. Consequently, the driving mechanism forms a triangular truss in which crank A0D and link DA1 can be assumed as one link for the sake of simplicity. The statics and dynamics of a stair and the whole stairs should be comprehensively discussed. The general computing mechanics developed in the 1990s43,44 can be directly used to model the structural characteristics of the stairs. What follows will first build the structural dynamics of this triangular truss.

sec.title: Structural dynamics of the driving mechanism
sec.p:
Because the components of the foldable stairs are all thin and long straight links, one can suppose that the links are all Euler–Bernoulli beams. Suppose that the x1-axis is along the vertical rocker, C0A1, and y1-axis is perpendicular rightward to the link. The primary coordinate frame for C0A1 is shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
The primary coordinate system for the vertical rocker.

The differential equation of bending vibration of an Euler–Bernoulli beam pivoted at both ends45,46 in Figure 3 is (1)∂2∂x2(EIz∂2y(x,t)∂x2)+ρA∂2y(x,t)∂t2=0 where E denotes the Young’s elastic modulus, Iz the inertial moment of the section about the z-direction, ρ the linear density of mass, and A the sectional area of the beam. Suppose (2)y(x,t)=Y(x)sin(ωt+ϕ) where Y(x) represents the shape function of bending vibration at x, ω the frequency of a sine vibration, and φ the phase angle.
Also, assume that the mass is uniformly distributed within the whole link, equation (1) can be transformed into (3)d4Ydx4-ρAω2EIzY=0

The general solution of equation (3) is (4)Y(x)=C1cosh(λx)+C2sinh(λx)+C3cos(λx)+C4sin(λx) where λ=ρAω2/EIz4 and Ci(i=1,2,3,4) can be determined by the boundary conditions of the beam. Because the Euler–Bernoulli beam satisfies (5) {Θz=dYdxMz=EIdΘzdxQy=dMzdx where Θz represents the slope function of the beam around the z-direction, Mz the bending moment about the z-direction, and Qy the shearing force in y-direction.

Substituting equation (4) into equation (5) and associating equation (4) presents (6)ξ4×1(x)=B4×4(x)[C1C2C3C4] where (7)ξ4×1(x)=[Y(x)Θz(x)Qy(x)Mz(x)]T (8)B4×4(x)=[cosh(λx)sinh(λx)cos(λx)sin(λx)λsinh(λx)λcosh(λx)-λsin(λx)λcos(λx)EIλ3sinh(λx)EIλ3cosh(λx)EIλ3sin(λx)-EIλ3cos(λx)EIλ2cosh(λx)EIλ2sinh(λx)-EIλ2cos(λx)-EIλ2sin(λx)] When x = 0, there is (9)B4×4(0)=[10100λ0λ0EIλ30-EIλ3EIλ20-EIλ20]
Substituting equation (9) into equation (6) yields (10)[C1C2C3C4]=B4×4 -1(0)ξ4×1(0) where (11)ξ(4×1)(0)=[Y(0)Θz(0)Qy(0)Mz(0)]T (12)B4×4 -1(0)=[120012EIλ2012λ12EIλ301200-12EIλ2012λ-12EIλ30]

Substituting equation (10) into equation (6) results in (13)ξ4×1(x)=H4×4(x)ξ4×1(0) where (14)H4×4(x)=B4×4(x)B4×4 -1(0)=[cosh(λx)+cos(λx)2sinh(λx)+sin(λx)2λsinh(λx)-sin(λx)2EIλ3cosh(λx)-cos(λx)2EIλ2λ[sinh(λx)-sin(λx)]2cosh(λx)+cos(λx)2cosh(λx)-cos(λx)2EIλ2sinh(λx)+sin(λx)2EIλEIλ3[sinh(λx)+sin(λx)]2EIλ2[cosh(λx)-cos(λx)]2cosh(λx)+cos(λx)2λ[sinh(λx)-sin(λx)]2EIλ2[cosh(λx)-cos(λx)]2EIλ[sinh(λx)-sin(λx)]2sinh(λx)+sin(λx)2λcosh(λx)+cos(λx)2]
Suppose (15) {R(x)=coshx+cosx2S(x)=sinhx+sinx2U(x)=coshx-cosx2V(x)=sinhx-sinx2
Substituting equation (15) into equation (14) yields (16)H4×4(x)=[R(λx)S(λx)λV(λx)EIλ3U(λx)EIλ2λV(λx)R(λx)U(λx)EIλ2S(λx)EIλEIλ3S(λx)EIλ2U(λx)R(λx)λV(λx)EIλ2U(λx)EIλV(λx)S(λx)λR(λx)]

The differential equation of longitudinal vibration of the link shown in Figure 3 is (17)EA∂2X(x,t)∂x2-ρA∂2X(x,t)∂t2=0 Suppose (18)X(x,t)=X(x)sin(ωt+ϕ) where X(x) denotes the longitudinal vibration shape function of x.

Substituting equation (18) into equation (17), one obtains the general solution of the shape function of longitudinal vibration mode of the beam (19)X=D1cos(kx)+D2sin(kx) where k=ωρ/E, and Di(i=1,2) can be determined from the boundary conditions.
The axial inner force of the link is (20)Qx=-EA∂X∂x=D1EAksin(kx)-D2EAkcos(kx)

Associating equations (19) and (20), one obtains (21)ξ2×1(x)=B2×2(x)[D1D2] where ξ2×1(x)=[XQx], B2×2(x)=[cos(kx)sin(kx)EAksin(kx)-EAkcos(kx)] Consequently, one has (22)[D1D2]=B2×2 -1(0)ξ2×1(0) where B2×2(0)=[100-EAk] and ξ2×1(0)=[X(0)Qx(0)]

Substituting equation (22) into equation (21) presents (23)ξ2×1(x)=H2×2(x)ξ2×1(0) where (24)H2×2(x)=B2×2(x)B2×2 -1(0)=[cos(kx)-sin(kx)EAkEAksin(kx)cos(kx)] When x=l1, H2×2(x) denotes the transfer matrix from the state vector of x = 0 to the state vector of x=l1. Within the xoy-plane, the link has both bending and longitudinal vibrations. Suppose that the state vector of the ith section is denoted by (ξ6×1)i=[XYΘzQxQyMz]i T, from equations (16) and (24), the (i+1)th state vector of the link can be expressed as (25)(ξ6×1)i+1=H6×6(x)(ξ6×1)i where (26)H6×6(x)=[cos(kx)00-sin(kx)EAk000R(λx)S(λx)λ0V(λx)EIλ3U(λx)EIλ20λV(λx)R(λx)0U(λx)EIλ2S(λx)EIλEAksin(kx)00cos(kx)000EIλ3S(λx)EIλ2U(λx)0R(λx)λV(λx)0EIλ2U(λx)EIλV(λx)0S(λx)λR(λx)]

With equation (25), the state vector of the ith joint is transferred to the (i+1)th joint. For example, the state vector of joint C0 shown in Figure 4 is now transferred to joint A1 in the primary coordinate frame, x3A1y3 (27)(ξ6×1)A11=R6×6(α13)H6×6(l1)(ξ6×1)C0 where A11 is the joint A1 represented in the first coordinate system, and similarly, Aij(i,j=1,2,…) is the joint Ai represented in the jth coordinate system, and (28)R6×6(α13)=[cosα13sinα130000-sinα13cosα130000001000000cosα13sinα130000-sinα13cosα130000001] and R6×6(α13) denotes the transformation matrix from frame x1A1y1 to frame x3A1y3, α13=π2 which denotes the subtended angle from x1-axis to x3-axis. (ξ6×1)A11=[XA1YA1ΘzA11QxA11QyA11MzA1]3 T, [·]i(i=1,2,…) represents that the state vectors are expressed in the ith coordinate frame, and (ξ6×1)C0=[XC0YC0ΘzC0QxC0QyC0MzC0]3 T. Figure 4.
The primary coordinate system for link A0DA1.

Substituting equations (26) and (28) into equation (27) yields (29)(ξ6×1)A11=[0R(λl1)S(λl1)λ0V(λl1)EIλ3U(λl1)EIλ2-cos(kl1)00sin(kl1)EAk000λV(λl1)R(λl1)0U(λl1)EIλ2S(λl1)EIλ0EIλ3S(λl1)EIλ2U(λl1)0R(λl1)λV(λl1)-EAksin(kl1)00-coskl1000EIλ2U(λl1)EIλV(λl1)0S(λl1)λR(λl1)](ξ6×1)C0
However, because C0 is pivot jointed, the known boundary conditions for joint C0 are (30) {XC0=0YC0=0MzC0=0

Equation (29) can be rewritten with the known criteria expressed in equation (30) as (31)(ξ6×1)A11=[XA11YA11ΘzA11QxA11QyA11MzA11]3= [S(λl1)λ0V(λl1)EIλ30sin(kl1)EAk0R(λl1)0U(λl1)EIλ2EIλ2U(λl1)0R(λl1)0-cos(kl1)0EIλV(λl1)0S(λl1)λ][ΘzC0QxC0QyC0]

Suppose that the primary coordinate frame of the link, A0DA1, is similarly set, namely, x-axis is along the axial direction of the link and y-axis passes through the fixed joint A0 and is perpendicular upward to A0DA1. One can therefore write out the transfer expressions from the state vector of joint A0 to joint A1 in the coordinate frame, x3A1y3, shown in Figure 4 (32)(ξ6×1)A12=R6×6(α23)H6×6(L)(ξ6×1)A0 where (ξ6×1)A0 =[XA0 YA0 ΘzA0 QxA0 QyA0 MzA0]3 T, L=l1/sinα23 and here α23=π/4 which represents the subtended angle between the x2- and x3-axes.

Expanding equation (32), one gains (33)(ξ6×1)A12=22[cos(kL)R(λL)S(λL)λ-sin(kL)EAkV(λL)EIλ3U(λL)EIλ2-cos(kL)R(λL)S(λL)λsin(kL)EAkV(λL)EIλ3U(λL)EIλ202λV(λL)2R(λL)02U(λL)EIλ22S(λL)EIλEAksin(kL)EIλ3S(λL)EIλ2U(λL)cos(kL)R(λL)λV(λL)-EAksin(kL)EIλ3S(λL)EIλ2U(λL)-cos(kL)R(λL)λV(λL)02EIλ2U(λL)2EIλV(λL)02S(λL)λ2R(λL)](ξ6×1)A0
The known boundary conditions for joint A0 are (34) {XA0=0YA0=0MzA0=0

With the known criteria of equation (34), equation (33) can be simplified as (35)(ξ6×1)A12=[XA12YA12ΘzA12QxA12QyA12MzA12]3=22[S(λL)λ-sin(kL)EAkV(λL)EIλ3S(λL)λsin(kL)EAkV(λL)EIλ32R(λL)02U(λL)EIλ2EIλ2U(λL)cos(kL)R(λL)EIλ2U(λL)-cos(kL)R(λL)2EIλV(λL)02S(λL)λ][ΘzA0QxA0QyA0]
Because A1 is pivot jointed, the following relation must hold (36)MzA11=MzA12=0
Substituting equation (31) into equation (36) yields (37)EIλV(λl1)ΘzC0+S(λl1)λQyC0=0
From equation (37), one obtains that (38)ΘzC0=-S(λl1)EIλ2V(λl1)QyC0

So, ΘzC0 is the function of QyC0. Substituting equation (38) into equation (31) yields (39)(ξ6×1)A11=[XA11YA11ΘzA11QxA11QyA11MzA11]3=PC0A1[QxC0QyC0] where PC0A11=[0V2(λl1)-S2(λl1)EIλ3V(λl1)sin(kl1)EAk00U(λl1)V(λl1)-R(λl1)S(λl1)EIλ2V(λl1)0R(λl1)V(λl1)-S(λl1)U(λl1)V(λl1)-cos(kl1)000]
Substituting equation (35) into equation (36) yields (40)EIλV(λL)ΘzA0+S(λL)λQyA0=0
From equation (40), one obtains (41)ΘzA0=-S(λL)EIλ2V(λL)QyA0

So, ΘzA0 is a function of QyA0. Substituting equation (41) into equation (35) yields (42)(ξ6×1)A12=[XA12YA12ΘzA12QxA12QyA12MzA12]3=PA0A12[QxA0QyA0] Where PA0A12=22[-sin(kL)EAkV2(λL)-S2(λL)EIλ3V(λL)sin(kL)EAkV2(λL)-S2(λL)EIλ3V(λL)02[U(λL)V(λL)-R(λL)S(λL)]EIλ2V(λL)cos(kL)R(λL)V(λL)-S(λL)U(λL)V(λL)-cos(kL)R(λL)V(λL)-S(λL)U(λL)V(λL)00]

Because links C0DA1 and B0A1 are all pivot jointed at A1, (ξ6×1)A11 and (ξ6×1)A12 must have identical coordinates when they are transformed into coordinate frame x3A1y3. (43)[XA1YA1]3=[XA11YA11]3=[XA12YA12]3
Therefore, associating equations (39) and (42), one obtains [0V2(λl1)-S2(λl1)EIλ3V(λl1)sin(kl1)EAk0][QxC0QyC0] (44) =22[-sin(kL)EAkV2(λL)-S2(λL)EIλ3V(λL)sin(kL)EAkV2(λL)-S2(λL)EIλ3V(λL)][QxA0QyA0]

As a result, [QxC0QyC0] can be expressed as a function of [QxA0QyA0] (45)[QxC0QyC0]=PC0A0[QxA0QyA0] where PC0A0=22[sin(kL)sin(kl1)Ak[V2(λL)-S2(λL)]Iλ3V(λL)sin(kl1)-Iλ3V(λl1)sin(kL)Ak[V2(λl1)-S2(λl1)]V(λl1)[V2(λL)-S2(λL)]V(λL)[V2(λl1)-S2(λl1)]]
Substituting equation (45) into equation (39) generates (46)(ξ6×1)A11=[XA11YA11ΘzA11QxA11QyA11MzA11]3=PC0A1PC0A0[QxA0QyA0]

Because A1 is pivot jointed by three links, the bending moments and slopes cannot be transferred between each other while keeping the same values of x- and y-displacements. As a result, associating equations (42) and (46), one gains (47)(ξ6×1)A1 output=[XA1YA1ΘzA1QxA1QyA1MzA1]3=PD[QxA0QyA0] where PD=PA0A12+E1PC0A1PC0A0 and E1=[000000000000000000000100000010000000]
Equation (43) expresses the state vector of joint A1 under the associated inputs of links C0A1 and A0DA1 with the unknown variables of joint A0, namely [QxA0QyA0]T.

The dynamic properties of the driving mechanism under the working position shown in Figure 4 can be obtained when other links are omitted. Under this condition, [QxA1QyA1]=0, namely (48)TQPD[QxA0QyA0]=0 where TQ=[000100000010] represents force interception matrix.
Because ςFA0=[QxA0QyA0] is a nonzero two-dimensional vector, one immediately gains the frequency determinant (49)|TQPD|=0 where |·| denotes the determinant of ‘ ·’.
Solving equation (49), one obtains the master frequency of the driving mechanism in the working position.

sec.title: Structural dynamics of the driving mechanism and a stair
sec.p: In a similar way, one can investigate the transfer matrix of state vector of link A1C1B1. For the horizontal beam, A1C1B1, two ends of which are all free of bending moments, the slope of beam A1C1B1, denoted by θH1, is an independent variable. As a result, the state vector for the horizontal beam A1C1B1 can be rewritten as (50)(ξ6×1)A1=[XA11YA11θH1QxA11QyA11MzA11]3=PD[QxA0QyA0]+θH1e6(3) where e6(3)=[001000]T.

With equation (25), one can transfer the associated state vector of A1, represented by equation (50), along the x3-direction, shown in Figure 5, to joint C1 (51)(ξ6×1)C11=[XC11YC11ΘzC11QxC11QyC11MzC11]3=PA1C1[QxA0QyA0]+θH1H6×6(l2)e6(3) where PA1C1=H6×6(l2)PD. Figure 5.
The coordinate system for the vertical beam B0C1.

Obviously, the vertical link B0C1 shown in Figure 5 provides two forces to joint C1 along x3- and y3-axes, respectively. For the sake of simplicity, one assumes that the joint forces exerted to A1C1B1 by link B0C1 are (52)FC11=[FxC11FyC11] where FxC11 represents the component force in x3-direction and FyC11 represents the component force in y3-direction. So, the output state vector of joint C1 along link A1C1B1 should be (53)(ξ6×1)C11 output=[XC11YC11ΘzC11QxC11QyC11MzC11]3 output=PA1C1[QxA0QyA0] +TQ TFC11+θH1H6×6(l2)e6(3) With equation (25), one can transfer the state vector, (ξ6×1)C11 output, represented by equation (53), along the x3-direction, shown in Figure 5, to joint B1 (54)(ξ6×1)B1 output=[XB11YB11ΘzB11QxB11QyB11MzB11]3=H6×6(l2)PA1C1[QxA0QyA0]+H6×6(l2)TQ TFC11+θH1H6×6 2(l2)e6(3)
Suppose that the state vector of joint B0 is denoted by (55)(ξ6×1)B0=[XB0YB0ΘzB0QxB0QyB0MzB0]4 T
The known boundary conditions for joint B0 are (56) {XB0=0YB0=0MB0=0

The vertical input state vector for joint C1 from joint B0 can be similarly denoted by (57)(ξ6×1)C12=[XC12YC12ΘzC12QxC12QyC12MzC12]4=PB0[ΘzB0QxB0QyB0] where PB0=[0-sin(kl1)EAk0S(λl1)λ0V(λl1)EIλ3R(λl1)0U(λl1)EIλ20cos(kl1)0EIλ2U(λl1)0R(λl1)EIλV(λl1)0S(λl1)λ]

Similarly, the vertical link B0C1 shown in Figure 5 will bear two reaction forces along x4- and y4-axes from the horizontal link A1C1B1 at joint C1 (58)FC12=-A(-π2)FC11=A(π2)[FxC11FyC11] where FC12 represents the joint force vector, A(β)=[cosβsinβ-sinβcosβ]β=π2=[01-10] a rotational transformation about z-axis for β angle, FxC11 the x-component of joint force at C11, and FyC11 the y-component of joint force at C11.
So, the output state vector of joint C1 along the x4-direction should be (59)(ξ6×1)C12 output=[XC12YC12ΘzC12QxC12QyC12MzC12]4 output=PB0[ΘzB0QxB0QyB0] +TQ TA(π2)[FxC11FyC11]
Because C1 is pivot jointed, the following relation must hold from Figure 5 (60)[XC11YC11]3 output=[XC12YC12]3 output=A(π2)[XC12YC12]4 output
In addition, both joints B1 and C1 shown in Figure 5 are all free of external forces. Therefore, one has (61) { [QxB11QyB11MzB11 ]3=0 [QxC12QyC12MzC12 ]4=0

Associating equations (60) and (61), and substituting equations (53), (54), and (59) into them yields (62)[XC11-YC12YC11+XC12¯QxB11QyB11MzB11¯QxC12QyC12MzC12]=T8×8[QxA0QyA0¯FxC11FyC11¯θH1¯ΘzB0QxB0QyB0]=0 where T8×8=[[TCPA1C1]2×2[TCTQ T-A(π2)TCTQ TA(π2)]2×2[TCH6×6(l2)e6(3)]2×1-[A(π2)TCPB0]2×3[E3×6H6×6(l2)PA1C1]3×2[E3×6H6×6(l2)TQ T]3×2[E3×6H6×6 2(l2)e6(3)]3×1[0]3×3[0]3×2[E3×6TQ TA(π2)]3×2[0]3×1[E3×6PB0]3×3]

Here, TC=[100000010000] represents an intercepting operation on a vector, TQ=[000100000010] the force intercepting operation on a vector, E3×6=[000100000010000001] an intercepting operation on a matrix and [0]m×n(m,n=2,3,…) denotes the m × n-dimensional zero matrix.
Hence, the frequency determinant of the stair shown in Figure 5 is expressed as (63)|T|=0 where T=T8×8 for the case shown in Figure 5.

With a set of parameters shown in Table 1, one can obtain the numerical results for the master frequencies of the foldable stairs from equation (63). Table 1.
Parameters of the links of the foldable stairs.
ρ(kg/m3) E(Pa) A(m2) I(m4) l1(m) l2(m)
7850 2.06×1011 1.2×10-3 3.6×10-7 0.3 0.3

Simulations under the same size and material conditions via ANSYS are executed to check the theoretical results. Comparisons between theoretical results and the simulations are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Comparisons for the first stair.
Order Simulations in ANSYS (Hz) Numerical results (Hz) Relative errors (%)
1 347.1891 349.2178 0.5843
2 668.5764 670.6153 0.3050
3 847.6745 853.3251 0.6666
4 1498.9546 1521.7122 1.5182
5 1638.8323 1665.0472 1.5996
6 1675.2331 1700.7297 1.5220

Comparisons indicate that the numerical results based on the theoretical analysis are very close to the simulation results through ANSYS. For the sake of clarity, the corresponding normal vibration modes obtained from ANSYS are illustrated in Figure 6, where the bold curves indicate the normal vibration modes, the hidden lines the undeformed shapes, the larger triangles the constrained DOFs, and the smaller triangles the coupled DOFs. These conventions will be adopted in the following figures from ANSYS in this article. Figure 6.
The first six normal modes of the driving mechanism and the first stair.

sec.title: Structural dynamics of the foldable stairs
sec.p:
Beamlet transforms provide an effective, relatively easy, and fast method for the extraction of curvilinear features such as cracks in pavement images.47 Similarly, the foldable stairs can be thought of as the serial connection of the driving four-bar mechanism, A0DA1C0, and a number of identical SLEs, Ai+1Ci+1Bi+1-BiCi+1Ai+2(i=0,1,2,…), shown in Figure 7. Therefore, one can investigate the transfer of the state vectors through these SLEs. Figure 7.
Transfer of the state vectors for an SLE.

sec.title: Transfer of the state vectors through SLEs
sec.p:
When an SLE is pivot jointed with A1 and the fixed joint B0, respectively, which is shown in Figure 8, the transfer algorithm for link B0C1 is also obtained in a similar way with equations (53) and (54). Figure 8.
Transfer of the state vectors for the first SLE.

With a process discussed in ‘Structural dynamics of the driving mechanism and a stair’ section, one obtains the state vector of B1, represented by equation (54) and the output state vector of joint C1 along x4-direction represented by equation (59). The output state vector of joint A2 along the x4-direction shown in Figure 8 will be discussed next. According to equation (25), one immediately gains (64)(ξ6×1)A2 output=[XA21YA21ΘzA21QxA21QyA21MzA21]4 output=H6×6(l1)PB0[ΘzB0QxB0QyB0] +H6×6(l1)TQ TA(π2)[FxC11FyC11] where H6×6(l1) represents the transfer matrix from joint C1 to joint A2 in the coordinate frame x4B0y4.

Because C1 is pivot jointed, relation (60) must also hold. Besides, both joint B1 and joint A2 shown in Figure 8 are all free of external forces. Therefore, one has (65) { [QxB11QyB11MzB11 ]3=0 [QxA21QyA21MzA21 ]4=0

Associating equations (60) and (65), and substituting equations (53), (54), (59), and (64) into them yields (66)[XC11-YC12YC11+XC12¯QxB11QyB11MzB11¯QxA21QyA21MzA21]=T8×8[QxA0QyA0¯FxC11FyC11¯θH1¯ΘzB0QxB0QyB0]=0 where (67)T8×8=[[TCPA1C1]2×2[TCTQ T-A(π2)TCTQ TA(π2)]2×2[TCH6×6(l2)e6(3)]2×1-[A(π2)TCPB0]2×3[E3×6H6×6(l2)PA1C1]3×2[E3×6H6×6(l2)TQ T]3×2[E3×6H6×6 2(l2)e6(3)]3×1[0]3×3[0]3×2[E3×6H6×6(l1)TQ TA(π2)]3×2[0]3×1[E3×6H6×6(l1)PB0]3×3]
As a result, one obtains the frequency equation of the stair shown in Figure 8 by substituting equation (67) into equation (63).

With a set of parameters shown in Table 1, one can obtain the numerical results from equation (63). In addition, simulations through ANSYS are also executed. Comparisons between theoretical results and the simulations are listed in Table 3. Table 3.
Comparisons for the first SLE.
Order Simulations in ANSYS (Hz) Numerical results (Hz) Relative errors (%)
1 324.3277 325.8857 0.4804
2 347.4973 349.5361 0.5867
3 673.7953 676.7905 0.4445
4 836.1196 842.4708 0.7596
5 1529.8605 1553.6069 1.5522
6 1568.0679 1578.9125 0.6916

Comparisons indicate that the numerical results based on the theoretical model are very close to the simulation results in ANSYS. For the sake of clarity, the corresponding normal modes obtained from ANSYS are illustrated in Figure 9. Figure 9.
The first six normal modes of the driving mechanism and the first SLE.

sec.title: Structural dynamics of the foldable stairs
sec.p:
Suppose that the ith(i=1,2,…) SLE is pivot jointed with the driving mechanism correspondingly, which is shown in Figure 10. Two ends of the vertical link BiCi+1Ai+2 and the horizontal link Ai+1Ci+1Bi+1 are all free of bending moments. As a result, the slopes of links BiCi+1Ai+2 and Ai+1Ci+1Bi+1, denoted by θVi and θHi+1, respectively, are two independent variables. Figure 10.
Transfer of the state vector for the ith SLE.

For the vertical link, A1C1B1, two ends of which are all free of bending moments, the slope of beam BiCi+1Ai+2, denoted by θVi, is a new independent variable. As a result, the input state vector for the vertical link BiCi+1Ai+2 can be rewritten as (68)(ξ6×1)Bi input=T6×6(-π2)[XBi1YBi10QxBi1QyBi10]2i+1 output+θVie6(3)

Similarly, for the horizontal beam, Ai+1Bi+1Ci+1, one can induce a new slope, denoted by θHi+1. The input state vector for joint Ai+1 in the 2(i+1)th coordinate frame will be (69)(ξ6×1)Ai+1 input=T6×6(π2)[XAi1YAi10QxAi1QyAi10]2(i+1) output+θHi+1e6(3)

With equation (25), the state vectors expressed by equations (68) and (69) are transferred to the cross-joint Ci+1 (70)[(ξ6×1)Ci+1 input]2(i+2)=-H6×6(l1)T6×6(π2)[XBi1YBi10QxBi1QyBi10]2i+1 output +θViH6×6(l1)e6(3) (71)[(ξ6×1)Ci+1 input]2i+3=H6×6(l2)T6×6(π2)[XAi1YAi10QxAi1QyAi10]2(i+1) output +θHi+1H6×6(l2)e6(3)

The vertical link BiCi+1Ai+2 shown in Figure 10 will exert two forces along x2i+3- and y2i+3-axes, respectively, on joint Ci+1 of the horizontal beam Ai+1Ci+1Bi+1. For the sake of simplicity, one assumes that the joint forces provided to Ai+1Ci+1Bi+1 by link BiCi+1Ai+2 are (72)FC(i+1)1=[FxC(i+1)1FyC(i+1)1] where FxC(i+1)1 represents the force in x2i+3-direction and FyC(i+1)1 represents the force in y2i+3-direction. In accordance with equation (71), the output state vector of joint Ci+1 along link Ai+1Ci+1Bi+1 should be (73)[(ξ6×1)C(i+1)1 output]2i+3=[XCi1YCi1ΘzCi1QxCi1QyCi1MzCi1]2i+3 output =H6×6(l2)T6×6(π2)E3[XAi1YAi1ΘzAi1QxAi1QyAi1MzAi1]2(i+1) output +θHi+1H6×6(l2)e6(3)+TQ T[FxC(i+1)1FyC(i+1)1] where E3=[100000010000000000000100000010000000] represents an intercepting operation on a vector.

Similarly, the vertical link BiCi+1 shown in Figure 10 will bear two reaction forces along xi+5- and yi+5-axes from the horizontal link Ai+1Ci+1Bi+1 at joint Ci+1 (74)FC2(i+2)2=-A(-π2)FC(2i+3)1=A(π2)FC(2i+3)1

So, according to equation (70), the output state vector of joint Ci+1 along the x2(i+2)-direction should be [(ξ6×1)C(i+1)2 output]2(i+2)=[XC(i+1)2YC(i+1)2ΘzC(i+1)2QxC(i+1)2QyC(i+1)2MzC(i+1)2]2(i+2) output (75)=-H6×6(l1)T6×6(π2)E3[XBi1YBi1ΘzBi1QxBi1QyBi1MzBi1]2i+1 output +θViH6×6(l1)e6(3)+TQ TA(π2)[FxC(i+1)1FyC(i+1)1] With equation (25), the state vector, [(ξ6×1)C(i+1)1 output]2i+3 and [(ξ6×1)C(i+1)2 output]2(i+2) can be transferred to joints Bi+1 and Ai+2: (76)[(ξ6×1)B(i+1)1 output]2i+3=[XB(i+1)1YB(i+1)1ΘzB(i+1)1QxB(i+1)1QyB(i+1)1MzB(i+1)1]2i+3 output =H6×6 2(l2)T6×6(π2)E3[XAi1YAi1ΘzAi1QxAi1QyAi1MzAi1]2(i+1) output +θHi+1H6×6 2(l2)e6(6) (77)[(ξ6×1)A(i+2)1 output]2(i+2)=[XA(i+2)1YA(i+2)1ΘzA(i+2)1QxA(i+2)1QyA(i+2)1MzA(i+2)1]2(i+2) output =-H6×6 2(l1)T6×6(π2)E3[XBi1YBi1ΘzBi1QxBi1QyBi1MzBi1]2i+1 output +θViH6×6 2(l1)e6(6)
The known boundary conditions for joints Bi+1 and Ai+2 are (78) {XB(i+1)1=0YB(i+1)1=0MB(i+1)1=0XA(i+2)1=0YB(i+2)1=0MB(i+2)1=0
Because Ci+1 is pivot jointed, the following relation must hold from Figure 10 (79)[XC(i+1)1YC(i+1)1]2i+3 output-A(π2)[XC(i+1)2YC(i+1)2]2(i+2) output=0

With a set of parameters shown in Table 1, one can obtain the numerical results by substituting equation (81) into equation (63). Suppose that there are 8-level stairs. When the last stair is free of any constraint, the whole deployed stairs form a structural cantilever and the last level’s constraints are given by the following equation (82) {QxC81=0QyC81=0MzC81=0QxC82=0QyC82=0MzC81=0XC81-YC82=0YC81+XC82=0

Comparisons between theoretical results and simulations through ANSYS are listed in Table 4. Comparisons reveal that the numerical results based on theoretical formulas are very close to the simulation results in ANSYS. For the sake of clarity, the corresponding normal modes obtained from ANSYS are illustrated in Figure 11. Figure 11.
The first six normal modes of 8-level stairs with no terminal constraint. Table 4.
Comparisons for the 8-level stairs with no terminal constraint.

When the last stair is fixed, the last level’s constraints become (83) {QC81=0QC81=0MzC81=0XC82=0YyC82=0MzC82=0XC81-YC82=0YC81+XC82=0

Comparisons between the theoretical results and the simulations through ANSYS are listed in Table 5. Table 5.

Comparisons reveal that the numerical results based on the theoretical formulas are very close to the simulation results via ANSYS. For the sake of clarity, the corresponding normal modes obtained from ANSYS are illustrated in Figure 12. Figure 12.
The first six normal modes of an 8-level foldable stairs with fixed terminal constraints.

With a set of parameters shown in Table 1 and suppose that there are 15-level stairs, one can obtain the numerical results by substituting equation (81) into equation (63). When the last stair is free of any constraint, the whole deployed stairs form a structural cantilever and the last level’s constraints are given by the following equation set (84) {QxC151=0QyC151=0MzC151=0QxC152=0QyC152=0MzC151=0XC151-YC152=0YC151+XC152=0

Comparisons between theoretical results and simulations through ANSYS are listed in Table 6. Table 6.
Comparisons for the 15-level stairs with no terminal constraints.
Order Simulations in ANSYS (Hz) Numerical results (Hz) Relative errors (%)

When the last stair is fixed to the ground, the last level’s constraints are expressed by the following equations (85) {QC151=0QC151=0MzC151=0XC152=0YyC152=0MzC152=0XC151-YC152=0YC151+XC152=0

Comparisons between theoretical results and the simulations through ANSYS are listed in Table 7. Table 7.
Comparisons for the 15-level foldable stairs with fixed terminal constraints.
Order Simulations in ANSYS (Hz) Numerical results (Hz) Relative errors (%)
1 6.9779 6.9805 0.0378

Comparisons indicate that the numerical results based on the theoretical formulas are very close to the simulation results in ANSYS. Table 7 also shows that the 15-level stairs can be used to connect two adjacent floors whose distance is as far as 4.5 m.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article focuses on the structural dynamics of foldable stairs the revolute joints of which allow large displacements. And this will surely introduce a lot of additional constraint equations when building the structural dynamics by transfer-matrix method. Therefore, this article takes advantage of the fact that each stair is made up of identical SLEs and establishes the structural dynamics through assembling the transfer matrices. The driving mechanism of the stairs is a statically determined four-bar linkage and every deployable SLE forms one stair when being expanded. Consequently, it is very convenient to set up the structural dynamics of the whole stairs through assembling the transfer matrix of every SLE in turn. The frequency determinant of all stairs only subjects to the boundary conditions of the joints and therefore it utilizes the least number of variables.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by the Natural Science Foundation of Beijing under Grant 3112014, the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 50805083, a Foundation for the Author of National Excellent Doctoral Dissertation of China under Grant 200741 and the Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University.

ack.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge these support agencies. In addition, the authors are grateful to Mr. Ju Gao, Mr. Houlin Fang, Mr. Hongjie Guan, Mr. Shuai Cheng, Mr. Shuai Shi and Mr. Zhengmao Lu for their hard work and kind help in the design, manufacturing and assembly of the foldable stairs. Sincere thanks should also extend to the anonymous reviewers for their invaluable suggestions in improving the paper.

def.p: joint Ai represented in the jth coordinate system
m-dimensional vector whose nth entry is ‘1’ and other entries are all zeros
Young’s elastic modulus of the material of the link
moment of inertia about the z-axis and Iz=∫∫Ay2dA
frequency of mode function of longitudinal vibration of the beam
bending moment about the z-axis at (x,t)
mode function of x for the longitudinal vibration
vibration function of x for the longitudinal vibration
vibration function of x for the transversal vibration in the xoy-plane
mode function of bending vibration in the xoy-plane at x
slope function of the beam around the z-direction at x
eigenvalues of the characteristic equation of the beam
linear mass density of the beam
